ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about so many topics relating to statistical inference like exponential families, probability, hypothesis testing, mini-max, Bayesian estimators, MLE, asymptotic testing. I also worked on some calculus, probability, analysis, and linear algebra skills.
Statistical inference

I have learnt so much. From the basic concept of exponential family, to how to analyze the power of estimations. Especially about how to do Bayesian estimation, minmax estimation and how to analyze the asymptotic of the parameters. As well as the fact that the teacher always showed us detailed proofs of theorems, I learned some proof techniques.
Stats inference theory
I learned the mathematical foundations of statistical inference.
I learned about Bayesian and minimax estimation and about asymptotic behavior of estimators. This class built upon my math and statistics prepation.
Some more mathematical understanding of the topics taught in 242

In-depth treatment of CLT, LLN, Slutsky's lemma, continuous mapping theorem, Bayes estimation, minimax estimation, James-Stein estimation, hypothesis testing, Neyman-Pearson Lemma, Le Cam's 1st and 3rd lemmas, quadratic mean differentiability, local asymptotic normality, contiguity, convergence, domination, equivalence, sufficiency
I gained a more thorough understanding of theoretical statistics and decision theory. In particular my knowledge of finite sample estimation is greatly improved.
I learned a lot about decision theory, local asymptotic Le cam theory and some bayesian analysis. Overall I think I understand what an estimator should be and how to improve them.

systematic development of the mathematical theory of statistical 
inference, covering finite-sample and large-sample theory of statistical estimation and hypothesis testing
finite sample theory; asymptotic theory
Statistical Inference theories.
statistical inference including estimation and asymptotic theory in statistics

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The course covers a great amount of information. I would consider this a pro and a con. I feel like I would have been happy to spend an entire semester on some of the modules of the course. However, I appreciate having an introduction and baseline appreciation for so many topics in statistics.

I feel conflicted in regards to the homeworks. On one hand, they cover an array of questions, but I really wish there were more softball questions. Maybe these questions don't need to be graded like we just get an answer key. I know there are extra problems in the book, but without some sort of answers they really don't feel very helpful. I also know that we cover examples in class, but I like to have as many examples as possible. Additionally, many times example problems from class or the book will be some sort of unique case, which really makes it much less helpful for learning some new concept. I also don't agree with the strategy of struggling through a few problems. I say this in the sense of getting up to speed on a topic as fast and efficient as possible. I would agree that struggling on problems does have a benefit of preparing for what future research problems might hold, and it is probably an indicator of true mastery of a problem. To that end, I might suggest staggering homeworks where each week we have basically 2 sets of problems. One set of problems are the "easy" problems that are from the new material covered that week, and the "harder" problems are from the previous weeks material. Maybe the "easy" problems could be self-graded or maybe even peer-graded. 

I definitely endorse having weekly homework. That is great. While difficult to implement, I think some element of quizzing would be very helpful. It would maybe not need to be for a grade just some type of check on basic understanding of the material each week. 

If I were to suggest something really out there, I would suggest having a flipped class. Basically, we just watch recordings and go to class to work on homework problems/get extra explanation from the professor. Respectfully, there is not much interaction during class. It doesn't seem the most efficient use of student and professor time. I don't think poorly of Dr. Fan's teaching skills; I just think lecture in general is kind of inefficient.

Leqi's notes were extremely helpful. The lecture goes very fast, and I found it difficult to write everything down without using these notes as a template.
It's very challenging and covers a lot

There are many advantages. For example, the teacher started with the most basic concepts and then went on to explore more in-depth topics. I understood the nature of statistical inference focusing on what the parameters are and how to make estimates, inferring. Secondly, Prof.Zhou was very patient and shared with us the students' and her class notes, which were very important to me. I could make sure I didn't misunderstand or miss any important information. The assignments at the end of each lesson were always the right level of difficulty to ensure that I understood what the teacher had taught me in class.

The current analyses all have very ideal assumptions, but when I need to apply this knowledge in practice (e.g. machine learning filed), these assumptions are often not met. Perhaps the teacher could discuss more current topics. For example, how to apply these techniques in the analysis of machine learning.
A lot of important topics covered. Workload is a little large but this is a hard course so Im happy to spend a lot of time on it
I really like the course, The course is very rigorous in mathematics, and has a very clear statistics intuition.
Zhou is a great instructor; I just wish the lectures had been recorded since class can move fairly quickly.
I think the midterm could be redesigned so that it is a better test of the student's knowledge.

Strengths: homeworks reinforce class content, Zhou Fan is an excellent and clear lecturer, interesting and very engaging and rich content for those at the pinnacles of their statistical undergraduate careers
Weaknesses: very time-consuming
The speed this course moves at in the asymptotic unit was difficult to keep up with, especially in the section on local asymptotic normality.
I think Zhou Fan is a great teacher and he is very knowledgeable of the course. I do think he try to put to much material into the semester and we went over class time alot.
Its wonderful

strengths: The lectures are very clear and easy to understand; they helped me quickly understand a lot of things that were very difficult for me to understand when I taught myself; almost perfect notes

weakness: Personally, I think the lectures about finite sample theory and the first couple lectures of asymptotic theory can be compressed, and the second half of the asymptotic theory is more difficult to understand, and it might be better if this part is slower.
Prof. Zhou Fan is excellent! He gave the lectures in a clear and attractive way. Enjoyed all the lectures. May consider providing recordings of lectures so that students can review them when needed.

Strength: theoretically sound, good course structure, great assignments and materials.
Weakness: not so involved, less coorporation

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would recommend the course, but only if you needed to take a course at this level.
Only if you really want to do math/statistics research
Sure!
Yes! This course covers a lot of fundamental and advanced theory in statistical inference
Yes. If you want to pursue a Ph.D. in statistics, applied maths, or operation research, then you should take the course.

This is a difficult class where most of the students are in graduate school. It's not necessary if you want to do anything besides statistics for the sake of statistics, but it gave me a much better handle on probability.

I would if you have not seen enough math, I do not think you will get much out of it if you have taken measure theory and SDS 242/542. This class is simply a more pedantic version of SDS 242, also I found it mind-numbing boring.

I would highly recommend this course: it reinforces many of the concepts learned in 242 by going over their mathematical origins. You develop a solid understanding and appreciation of statistical advances over the years. It is excellently taught, and the TA's/ULA's were solid as well. Just be prepared to work: the workload is not for the faint of heart. Without intuition I'd gained from taking MATH 305 (real analysis) and S&DS 364 (information theory) in the past, truly comprehending some of the sufficiency, domination, and measure theoretic content would have been more difficult. I'll also say that these courses should not be seen as prerequisites: not knowing the detailed, Yale math department-level intuition behind a Lebesgue measure or an open set won't kill you in 410.
I would highly recommend this course to another student as long as they have sufficient mathematical background.
Yes, I think it's a must take for a statistics major.
Yes, its a hard and very useful

strongly recommend. This course is the most difficult one I have applied yet. This course can help students understand the content pretty well. The instructor Prof. Zhou gave me his intuitive explanation about sophisticated formula and theory.
Sure. This course is very informative, and Prof. Zhou Fan is an excellent instructor.
No
